Key Match Events: Jón Dagur Þorsteinsson scored the only goal of the game at Wembley in the 12th minute, finishing off a sharp break with a low shot through John Stones's legs to beat goalkeeper Aaron Ramsdale at his near post.
Anthony Gordon sliced his shot well over the bar when in a similar position to Þorsteinsson two minutes after the goal.
Captain Harry Kane missed a golden chance in the 28th minute when he shinned Cole Palmer's cross over from six yards out.
Þorsteinsson sliced horribly wide in the 63rd minute, missing a chance to double Iceland's lead.
Aaron Ramsdale was forced to save a Sverrir Ingason header and Kolbeinn Finnsson's audacious volley from the edge of the box.
Post-Match Reflections: Former England defender Matthew Upson described the performance as lacking width, directness, aggression, and physicality, calling it dismal and flat.
England coach Gareth Southgate acknowledged the disjointed and disappointing performance but considered it a good learning experience before the tournament.
Wayne Rooney emphasized the importance of players gaining experience from the game.
Joe Cole expressed confidence in the team's readiness for the tournament despite the disappointing result.
Others: England only managed one shot on target in the entire contest.
Southgate will have concerns over the fitness of centre back John Stones, who was replaced at half-time after appearing to roll his ankle in the first minute.
